title: iBall - An excercise ball for your iPhone

description.text: Is your iPhone getting slow and bloated as it ages? Liven it up with a bit of exercise using the iBall.

Print 2 of the cover half part and glue them together.
Print 1 copy each of the Ball top and bottom half parts and glue them together.
Insert iPhone into the iBall via the opening at the top.
Put the cover in place by lining up the tabs with the slots, lowering it onto the ball, and then twisting a quarter turn so the slots will hold it in place.
Give the ball a good kick or shove to help it get started. The iPhone should get the idea. 
Enjoy the benefits of a slim, healthy iPhone.

author: skeetersim

description.text:
Minimalist display brackets to mount the driver PCB to the display panel in order to prevent the flat flex cable from ripping out accidently and damaging any components (happened to me :-().

Note: this bracket is designed for the 8" HDMI/DVI/VGA/CVBS LCD display from Pollin electronic!

Print instructions: print the bracket laying on the side to prevent overhang area and filament rippling. You need to print the bracket twice. Use an M3 tap to create a thread in the holes (2.5 mm in diameter).

Important/TODO: the little holder-hook-thingies which hold on to the LCD need to fit snugly but not too tight since this could damage the module. I tweaked the fit with a knife. @TODO: maybe enlarging the width of the hooks (=larger surface) results in the pressure distributed more equally resulting in reducing the mechanical stress.

title: Amazon Echo Dot V2 Wall/Ceiling Mount

description.text:
Brilliant original design by halcyon can be found here - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1463045. I have had a lot of people ask for this to be printed and from their feedback I have updated it with some of my amends. These are as follows:

  • Added countersunk screw holes for mounting (I did ask halcyon for this and he updated his design, but I went for a more traditional UK bevel screw).
  • Moved the mount holes to line up with the USB/Audio holes - assuming cabled will run downwards/upwards from Echo Dot and gives a more secure mount if mounting into a wooden stud.
  • Added contoured sloped grooves in base to deflect audio from speaker outwards (may/may not make any difference in sound?!!) and to reduce plastic filament.
  • Added arches to speaker holes to reduce plastic filament use and to help reduce amount of bridging needed. Also looks nice!
  • Added support column in middle of USB/audio hole to help with bridging the gap. I found the bridged filament will naturally be a straight line, whereas the hole follows the curve of the mount, so I always had to clean out strings of filament which failed to bond. This halves the gap and there is no more clean up (for my setup). You can see it in the Cura image in the gallery, and the before and after shots. Just snap it out when printed.

If you like this design - hats off to halcyon first for the cool and chunky design! It is still as tight as the original, I like that security. If you want it to be loose - just sand down the inside a little.

Print Settings Below:
Printer: P3Steel Toolson Edition
Filament: Rigid.ink 1.75 PLA - Black (Amazon http://amzn.to/2fYxRZW)
Filament used: 12.31m 37.02g
Layer Height: 0.2mm
Temperature Ex1: 205°C
Temperature Bed: 65°C
Perimeters: 2 at 0.4mm (0.8mm total)
Infill: 20%
Raft: No
Brim: No
Support: None
Speed: 40mm/s
Time: About 3 hours 41 minutes
Scale: 100%

Timelapse of the print and my discussion about it: https://youtu.be/ElCpCcfPT6M

comments.text: Man! Really hard to squeeze her in! Will keep trying with sanding though!
comments.author: gtokarsk

comments.text: Glad you're finally getting there, as you have found - it does fit, it's just very tight. This design was based off a ceiling mount, so the tolerances had to be next to zero to allow the dot to be held in place with nothing but friction. A well tuned printer and good filament will allow the dot to be pushed in. Most require a little sanding to fine tune it. Some people have even said it was too loose, and use some electrical tape to help pack it in...(!!)

description.text:

description.text:
I've designed with autodesk fusion 360 an anemometer that I would like to use. It is attached to the mast of my sail-bot. It is based on two main hardware parts:

  • The GY-87 IMU
  • the 12.4mm 300Rpm 6 Wires 6 Conductors Capsule Slip Ring 240V AC for Monitor Robotic SRC012C

I didn't know about the existence of the second one, it is a very useful piece that allows to connect electric wires from two rotating components.

Both of them can be found for a few dollars on the web. The IMU will provide the wind heading and is placed in the anemometer rotating part while the second one will be placed between the rotating part of the anemometer and the base.

I'm wondering if to add a dc motor a the front extremity of the "arrow" in order to get some more electricity, probably in the next log I will add it :)

If you are interested in my project of an autonomous sailboat visit my project page on Hackaday :)
https://hackaday.io/project/10652-green-powered-sailboat

author: XxxK1NGXxX

title: Another -but different and geometrically proportionate- spaghetti measuring tool

description.text:
Perhaps it's my clumsiness, but I find the standard designs, based on round openings, hard to use. Either I end up with a fistful of spaghetti loosely dangling in the hole (hence eliminating the measurement goal) or individually squeezing -sometimes breaking- the last ones.

Moreover, I found that many of the "standard" published measures are simply not proportionate, i.e., the area of the hole for 2, 3 or 4 servings is substantially different (sometimes up to 22%) from 2, 3 or 4 times that of a single serving. Curiously, servings for 2 tend to be the smallest (vs. twice a single one). Perhaps trying to avoid criticism from weight-conscious partners :-) ? Check for yourselves if you don't believe me. The math is simple: Area = π (3.1416) times the square of the radius -in excel, +PI()*R^2-.

The "standard" individual serving also varies substantially, ranging from diameters of 17mm (0.67") to 23mm (0.91"). It may not seem much (35%), but when you square the radius, the difference in area amounts to 83%! Of course, traditional "index & thumb" rules will also be widely different (a "Boban Marjanović serving" will surely be plenty for anyone), but that's not the intent.

I've settled for a rough average of the most widespread "standards", equivalent to a 21mm (0.83") diameter for a single portion. And yes, the area for 2, 3 or 4 servings is exactly 2, 3 or 4 times bigger. If you find it too scarce or too generous, just scale it up or down, but be aware, any linear in-/decrease will yield a square in-/decrement. For example, a 10% linear upsize represents a 21% increase of the resulting portions (1.1x1.1=1.21), 20% (1.2x1.2=1.44) 44%, and so on. Still, large or small, the servings will remain proportionate.

About the design, I found the proposal (www.thingiverse.com/thing:961715) of Engineer89 inspiring. Not only his servings are exactly proportionate (as could be expected from an engineer, @ 350 mm2 each), it also allows to simply drop the spaghetti on top and remove the excess. However, it's a bit bulky to fit in our already packed kitchen drawers. So, I decided to "open up" the traditional circles and use instead appropriately resized semicircles. It's not as stable, but it does stand sideways reasonably well. All edges are rounded for additional safety.

Concerning printing, I've used PET-G to make it "dishwasher-safe", but almost any material will do. 30% infill seems strong enough, unless you want to print a wafer-thin version, in which case flexibility will be key (avoid PLA). Food compatibility should not be a concern because contact will be minimal and brief.

I've created two versions, one w/ roman numerals (+Braille on the top side) and a more symbolic -and easier to print w/ some materials- one. Besides STL, SKP, DXF and 3DM (Rhino 5) formats are also included, to facilitate remixing/personalization.

Happy printing -and cooking-!

Note: Upon use, I found that if the kitchen desktop is very smooth, dropped spaghetti tend to slide away. Put a non slippery mat under it, or place an adequate barrier (e.g., the spaghetti box/bag) aside to prevent it.

description.text:
This is a panel to hold a standard(?) LCD 44780 20x2 char screen. It has clamps to attach it to a 8mm rod
The LCD type I got is: TC2004A-03 in case it matters.
And yes, my print is not that good, but for a test is worked out pretty well.

A simple ball that is easy to print and has a retro mechanical look.  
It's a ball, an ornament, a dog or cat toy or even a toothbrush holder.  Make up your own games.  Nobody gets bored with a makerball in the house :)

Print six (6) makerbolt crown brackets from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:187737 and then twelve (12) makerbolts from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9095. Make sure to overlap the crown brackets consistently to avoid misalignments. It is easier if you define a top and work from there. I put the top and bottom brackets on the inside, then two opposite sides outside of them and then the other two sides outside of the first two sides. All the holes should line up if you align them consistently and symmetrically. If you want to hang it like an ornament, also print the hook. The hook was made for easy printing, so it prints upright and the hook portion is really an eye. Simply print it and then cut out a portion of one side with a pair of scissors or wire cutters. Those with obsessive-compulsive disorder may wish to align the M's on the ends of the bolts and fix them periodically :)

I needed a solder fume extractor and a solder spool holder, so I decided to combine to combine the two and attach it to a desk mounted articulating arm. This station will mount to anything with a 1/4"-20 nut and bolt. Also, check out my FreeCAD tutorial where I show how to make this model:
Part 1: https://youtu.be/ODfiM8l89vQ
Part 2: https://youtu.be/-1PyZEqtNh4

You will need the following things to make this station:
-120mm fan (get one that's rated at least 40+ CFM)
-Small toggle switch
-12 volt power source
-Carbon filter: http://amzn.to/2fZmyQW
-1/2" Wooden Dowel Rod
1/4"-20 Nut
-Articulating Ball Arm: http://amzn.to/2fvzAlm

I have included the FreeCAD Files for anyone to modify as well as a smaller version and a full sized version.

title: MiSUMi Linear Slide Parts for FTC Robotics

description.text: For use with MiSUMi extruded aluminum. These are the 3D printed parts we used to build our linear slide for our FTC robot in the RESQ season. There is one linear bearing that goes between two pieces of MiSUMi extruded aluminum, and one linear bearing that goes on the side of the linear slide. They lock onto one piece of extruded aluminum and slide in the other one. The final pieces may or may not be useful to you. They were shoved in the top and bottom of the slides, leaving a small gap at the ball bearings to keep the string from easily coming lose. There are 2 different lengths because we didn't mount our ball bearings at consistent places.

description.text:
With it’s project, Lucas Dauvergne suggests a way to limit the amount of domestic waste, with ludic, creative and useful upcycling processes.

The “material lab” made by the designer, with the collaboration of a textile designer, Valentine Rosi, explores the potential of domestic waste and results to four DIY kits turning trash contents into useful products.

The first kit presented here is a cartridge refill system with organic inks made from waste.
Please watch this video to get more informations about it : https://youtu.be/F5Tb57X_At8

Three others “do-it-yourself kits” are also available, including a simple and easy way to recycle bottles into drinking glasses, an urban composter that produces delicious mushrooms, and a red cabbage boiled water based solar lamp.

title: Farmhouse Advent Calendar (with tabs and slots)

description.text:
UPDATE Nov 28 2016: I remixed the key so it would fit more snugly.

Amazed by ClassyGoat's fantastic Farmhouse Advent Calendar, but intimidated by the building and gluing required? Got a big build area, like the Robo3D? Do you hate supports? Then this remix is for you! I made a few mechanical changes to make this easier to assemble:

  • The walls now have tabs for gluing them together - just apply glue to the tabs and clamp the walls together until they set. (I printed a few of these for the job: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1673030). You can see an example in the photos. I recommend Loc-Tite GO2 glue for everything.

  • The candy containers now print as part of the walls - you don't have to line them up and glue them. Instead, print out 24 of container_cap.stl and glue them on. (If you scale them down just a bit, they might snap on and stay without gluing.)

  • I made a new F1 floor - this one is a little larger, and more importantly has slots for the walls to fit into, to help with alignment and stability while gluing. The walls will fit in fairly tightly; you may have to sand, file or plane off a little plastic from the corners of the walls.

  • Because the walls sink a couple of millimeters into the floor, you'll need to print my rescaled F1 railing instead of the original so it'll fit the new clearance.

  • You may want to skip the Christmas Tree box; I'm not sure it will fit with the new built-in candy containers.

  • Last but not least, I made a single-piece roof. I actually printed it in ABS by using an enclosure to keep it from warping, but you'll probably have better luck with PLA. You will need a raft to print this, and you may want to lower the air gap on the raft so that it holds the piece tighter during the print, since it will be heavily cantilevered while printing.

Other than these, print the original pieces from ClassyGoat's design and assemble per those instructions. I printed all the remixed parts at 0.3mm with no supports.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

.15

Notes:

Rafts only needed for the roof

comments.text: I want to use this remix vs. the original but I don't think my Prusa MK2S volume will fit this version. Looks like I'm short an inch in comparison.
comments.author: BuddyLeeeee

comments.text: Coincidentally, that's the printer I have now - I got tired of replacing RAMPS boards on my Robo3D.  I haven't checked yet, is it the roof that doesn't fit?
comments.author: BuddyLeeeee

comments.text: I've started my run on this one. I had some printer issues before. I'm scaling up to 115%. I can't remember my infill. It was probably 15 or 20%. My first attempt at the west wall didn't go so well because of layer shifting. I have since corrected the printer issues and was successful at printing the east wall at 115%. The roof does fit the Prusa bed but I can only print in 10 hour increments. All other parts I can easily print under 10 hours. I'll post the finished product once I get a bit closer. Currently printing the floor. Plan to do the smaller parts over the weekend if time permits. The floor I decided to print at .35 whereas the others I believe I printed at .15mm.
comments.author: doctorjay

comments.text: I'm printing the roof on my Prusa i3 Mk2S right now in Christmas Red ABS... so far, so good at 65%.  I don't have an enclosure, so we'll see how well it does at the higher layers.  I tried to print it yesterday, but had some warping and then a Y-axis layer shift at about 85% done which ruined the whole thing.  (The new Mk3 would have detected that and fixed it!)
comments.author: BuddyLeeeee

title: Microscope adapter for Logitech web-cam lets you shoot video through your microscope

description.text:
Update: an improved version of this thing is found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:216821
I recommend using the newer verison...
A simple adapter that holds a Logitech Quickcam Pro for Notebooks at the correct position on a microscope to allow you to record video and still images of objects viewed under the microscope- ANY microscope.
With this particular web cam the lens needs to be held a few mm above the eyepiece lens, so I designed the holder to do just that. The adapter grips the aluminum piece that the eyepiece slides into, not the eyepiece itself, which fits loosely inside the adapter. That makes it easy to adjust the position of the camera/adapter for optimum results. If your print fits the camera a little loose, use a rubber-band to hold the camera more tightly to the adapter. I use GUVCViewer on my laptop (Ubuntu 13.04) to view results and capture video and still images. I am able to get 940x720 video at 15 fps with this setup. Test video can be seen here: https://vimeo.com/80511761
I made an adapter for a gopro camera, but the gopro lens captures such a wide field of view that the image from the microscope occupies only a small portion of the center of the field. An additional lens would be necessary to use a gopro for this purpose.
The outer diameters of microscope eyepiece and the of the tube it slides into (the aluminum part gripped by the adapter) are not standardized, so you may have to tweak the design to fit your microscope. My scope is a B&L Balplan recently picked up on ebay for about $200. I am using Leica 16X WF Kpl eyepieces.
The second photo is a dead bug squished by a cover slip. magnification is 160x.
The procedure for designing something like this is easy:
1) hold your camera up to the eyepiece of the microscope while viewing video on your computer. You'll have to move the camera around a bit to find the best position for it, and then visually estimate the distance from the camera lens (or the end of the lens tube) to the eyepiece lens.
2) measure the eyepiece and the eyepiece tube diameters with a caliper. You must be sure to align the optical centers of the camera and eyepiece lenses, so measure carefully.
3) design a mount to hold your camera with a tube that fits loosely over the eyepiece but grips the eyepiece tube. You'll be able to slide the mount up and down on the eyepiece tube to adjust the exact distance between the camera and eyepiece lenses.
The logitech camera I used has an unusual shape which made designing the adapter a little tricky. There are other cameras that have easier shapes to design around and better video performance, but this is the one I had handy.

I designed the part using Sketchup, exported the .stl file, sliced with slic3r, printed with support material using 1.75mm Coex3d blue ABS (thanks Chris Osborn!), 0.2mm layer thickness, 35% infill on the MegaMax printer at the Milwaukee Makerspace.

title: 3D PRINT FOOD - Icing 3D Printer modification for RepRap

description.text:
3D PRINT FOOD - Icing 3D Printer modification for RepRap
http://www.3dprintler.com/3dprintler-techlinks-ottawa-2013/
There was absolutely no better way we could have started Global Entrepreneurship Week (GEW) than attend TechLinks Ottawa. Yesterday, on Monday Nov. 18, the 3Dprintler team packed up our man-made 3D printer, camera equipment, business cards and cookies (for our “sweet” surprise), and we made our way to the Canadian Museum of Nature, where Exploriem held TechLinks Ottawa this year. We set up shop and the booth was soon buzzin’. We handed out 3Dprintler’s 3D-printed bottle openers. Moreover, Aitor, our lead engineer, used his 3D printer to put icing on the cookies, which we then shared with everyone who visited the booth—naturally everyone flocks where there are baked goods, right?

comments.text: Amusing but a better solution, just get rid of the two Z motors and use only one plus belts to drive the two Z screws ! Why do people spend so much time and effort to go around issuess instead of solving them ? Anti wobbling,  auto bed levelling for Cartesian machines, vibration dampeners etc...
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: You're right, but both solutions have pros and cons. :-)
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: There is ABSOLUTELY NO pros in using two motors ! It is a BASIC engineering mistake ! It is not even cheaper. It is the first thing I modified on my Geetech Prusa, no wobble, no vibration, no need to level the bed and of course no auto bed levelling.
comments.author: davtr

comments.text:
My printer has no wobble no vibrations as well. Of course you need to level the bed for the first time. And auto bed leveling - well I use it on MK2 rework only because it is in software and can't be turned off. But I use second printer based on the same design with classic 200x200 heatbed with glass and there is no auto bed leveling and there is no need of manual bed leveling either. I leveled the bed only once during first calibration.
Generally speaking - I noticed no problems primarily caused by "two motors engineering mistake". This thing is designed only to make like a bit easier when doing some tweaks on turned-off printer when it is easy to get Z axis off-level.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
Two steppers CAN and OFTEN will snap to different positions when powered on and off, leading to the same offset as when you "tweak" as you said. Can happen during operation too.
You will NEVER find this kind of set up in an industrial machine because IT IS an engineering mistake. A stepper motor is an OPEN loop system.
Wobble, vibration are not because of these two steppers of course. But at the same time I modified for one motor, I got good straight lead screws, got rid of the couplings and arranged to have the X carriage hung by the lead screws from the top of the frame. Just that even with thin M5 threaded rod, would reduce wobble to nothing.
I got rid of vibration by making the frame more rigid and making my own Igus bearings and dramatically reducing the Y table and X carriage weight.
comments.author: davtr

comments.text: No you're wrong MKSA. You do fine double lead screw designs in industrial machines. For example we have a Zorn machine vision tool that is for material surface inspection. You can imagine how precise a machine like that must be.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: Obviously you didn't understand what I said !
comments.author: Cormzilla

comments.text: "You will NEVER find this kind of set up in an industrial machine because IT IS an engineering mistake. A stepper motor is an OPEN loop system."
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: So in addition, you don't understand how this machine works !
comments.author: Cormzilla

comments.text: What. Explain to me where I'm making a mistake. You are an engineer, explain to me simply why I'm wrong. I don't think I am.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
I basically agree with you. There is one thing I don't like on your solution - Z axis coupling belt assembly on upper side of the frame. I got a lot of other stuff mounted on upper edge of the frame (spool holder, full graphic LCD, prepared for multi-material upgrade). If I ever tried to design such type of upgrade, I would placed it down under the bed to keep upper side free.
I will think about it. :-)
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
Initially I wanted to mount it underside but didn't, no much room and mechanically on the top, the lead screws pull the X carriage which is better to reduce wobble.
I would mount it on the bottom for other frame but not for a Prusa.
You shouldn't put the spool on the top as it is a heavy mass. I put it on the side, in the same plane as the X carriage so I have a nice natural loop going through just one guide (see my simple guide things) to the extruder. The filament is just going through PTFE tube BTW. Very smooth feed.
The Prusa frame is not very rigid BTW. It is why I don't like non metallic Prusa. In fact, I only believe in aluminum, steel, cast iron, granite, concrete :) unless it is a box frame
SO the less you put on it, the best.
comments.author: davtr

comments.text: I don't use original Prusa frame, my frame has plenty of space under bed, I definitely will think about coupling belt under the bed.
comments.author: MKSA

title: Motör-headphone Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Nota : the English version is below

L'idée de Lancu d'avoir un fond personnalisable est vraiment génial. Fan de Motörhead depuis maintenant plus de 35 ans, c'était pour moi une évidence d'associer cet objet musical à la musique que j'aime.
Merci Lancu d’avoir créé ce superbe support !

Mon support est un peu plus qu'un simple 'remix", car j'ai en fait tout refait. J'en ai d’ailleurs profité pour masquer la fixation avec le fond, que vous pourrez retirer en passant par le trou se situant en dessous du cadre.

Bien sûr, vous n'êtes pas obligé d'avoir le Snaggletooth en fond (quoique... :) ), mais pour ceux qui le souhaitent, voici un lien pour récupérer l'image : http://img.xooimage.com/files110/d/3/9/snaggletooth-50fd3f2.jpg

Rien de particulier pour l’impression, excepté peut être un "brim" pour le fond si vous n'avez pas de plateau chauffant.

Voilà, vous savez tout, et n'oubliez pas : "We are Motörhead, and we play Rock'N'Roll"
Tu nous manques Lemmy...

English version

My apologies for my approximate English...

The idea of Lancu to have a customizable background is really great. Fan of Motörhead now since more than 35 years, for me, it was a highlight to associate this musical object to the music that I like.
Thank you Lancu to have created this superb holder!

My holder is a little more than a simple 'remix", because I have any redesigned. I've taken the opportunity to hide the fixing with the background that you can remove by passing through the hole below the framework.

Of course, you are not obliged to have Snaggletooth in the background (although... :) ), but for those who wish, here is a link to download the image: Http://img.xooimage.com/files110/d/3/9/snaggletooth-50fd3f2.jpg

Nothing in particular for the printing, except a "brim" for the background plate if you do not have a heatbed.

That all, you know everything, and do not forget: "We are Motörhead, and we play rock'n'Roll"
Missing You Lemmy...

author: hantescu

description.text:
The cutter was designed for cutting icing snowflakes to go on a Christmas cake. The cutter and the plunger are drawn at the same scale and if enlarged or reduced ensure the scaling ratio is the same for both or the plunger won't fit.
Roll out the icing to the thickness you desire, press the cutter into it, use the plunger to release the icing snowflake.
The parts were drawn up in Fusion 360 and as this outputs a .stl file at 90 degrees I then load them into Cura to lay them flat. The cutter sits with the hexagon on the base.
The files used at the size they are produce a snowflake around 70mm dia. I reduced them in Cura to around 35 to 40 mm dia, I would be wary about reducing them any more than this to keep their definition. Once the size is worked out for the cutter take note of the scale ratio and use this for the plunger.
I printed mine in red PLA at a layer height of 0.2mm at 100% fill. No rafts, brims or supports are necessary.
The finished parts seem to be ok washed in hot water and then dried straight away. I would be wary about leaving them to soak in hot water (not sure what would happen) and definitely avoid a dishwasher.

print_settings.Notes:: Plase check out the instructions to see the recommended settings for each part.

description.text:
This is a life-sized (100 cm long!) replica of Mulan's sword, from the Disney animated film released in 1998.

The main goal of this model was to minimize the amount of external tools and materials required to build it. The pieces were designed in a way that you don't even need to paint it, as you can print each one of the sections using filament of the corresponding color!

Printing Instructions:

  • Guard.STL (2 times) : 0.15mm layer height, 40% infill, Supports enabled
  • Handle.STL : 2.0mm layer height, 40% infill, No supports needed
  • Ferrule.STL (2 times) : 0.15mm layer height, 40% infill, No supports needed
  • Pommel.STL : 2.0mm layer height, 40% infill, No supports needed
  • BladeTip.STL (2 times) : 0.20mm layer height, 10% infill, No supports needed
  • BladeA.STL (2 times) : 0.20mm layer height, 15% infill, Supports enabled
  • BladeB.STL (6 times*) : 0.20mm layer height, 40% infill, Supports enabled

Assembly:

1) Glue together the halves that make up the parts labeled BladeA, BladeB and BladeTip.

2) Assemble all the Blade pieces using superglue.

3) Put the rectangular ending of the Blade in one of the Guard halves. Make sure that it fits properly, and glue it. Then, cover it with the other half.

4) Put the Ferrules at the ends of the Handle, and press until they fit tightly.

5) Put the Pommel in the end of the Handle that doesn't have a rectangular hole.

6) Put glue at the rectangular end of the Blade that comes out of the Guard, and use it to join the Blade to the Handle.

Take a look at the attached pictures. The steps for the assembly are illustrated.

*You can change the sword's size by reducing or increasing the number of BladeB pieces. This way, you can adapt this design to the size of the person that will use it. Each one of the pieces adds or removes 180mm from the blade's lenght.

Flashforge Creator Pro 2016

Yes

I needed somewhere to hang my headphones when using my computer which is next to an Ikea Lack side table which has my 3D printer on. So i designed a simple mount that would slide over the side of the table. I have put double sided tape on the inside of it that touches the side of the table, this holds it solidly on the table.

The top area where you place your headphones is roughly 40mm from table edge to stand lip and 45mm wide side to side.

description.text: This water valve is controlled by a parallax 180 degree servo.

Printer:

JGAurora

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.4

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Printed on Blue Painters tap affixed to heated bed.

Light Sanding

The cylinder fits very tightly to prevent leaking. To fit the pieces together, you will need to use 400 grit sand paper and about ten turns on the valve itself and a few turns inside the valve body. I made a loop of the sand paper and put the valve in side the loop and turned in my hands about 10 turns. The valve should fit snug into the body and you should be able to turn it in the socket by hand with a little force. I used ABS and Acetone slurry to glue the valve cover to the body and the gear to the valve itself. Turning the valve when all assembled should take a little force and shouldn't require any tools.

This is the prop connector that is sometimes breaking. I have designed it for better printing and more durability, so the thing has not the original measurements.

After printing you must drill ALL 3 holes with 1,5mm and then the outer ones with 2mm.
It is a little bit tricky because you must drill straight and not to slow(2mm holes).
But the connector works nice :-)

Use threadlocker medium for the screws, so you dont need to full tighten the screws and you can adjust the tightness !

description.text:
Winter is here, and we Nissan LEAF owners gotta stick together just to stay warm. I know that gets awkward, so this year, let's try something different. We can supplement our heat with just a low wattage desktop heater. In the enclosed space of a car, this is even better because the heat stays inside!

My estimated miles were dropping like zombies on the Walking Dead every time I turned on the heat in my Nissan LEAF. So I researched how I could add a heat source that does not use the LEAF's fuel cell. A small 170 watt electric heater, and a small 220Wh battery pack with included charger and built-in 200 watt inverter gives me 1 hour and 10 minutes of heat per charge.

Here are links to the heater and battery pack on Amazon:
https://www.amazon.com/Honeywell-Heat-Personal-Heater-White/dp/B00X3PT9ZG/

https://www.amazon.com/Portable-Generator-Household-Storage-Inverter/dp/B018GE8JPY/

I added another optional part: D_Battery_Stabilizer.stl. Print 2 (or 3) of these to clamp onto the base of the Suaoki 220Wh battery pack. This will help to keep the battery upright in the floor when you are making sharp turns. My goal was for the battery to sit on the hump in the back, but it still tumbles. The floor is the safest place for the battery for now.

If you find something that works better, please leave a link in a comment.
Enjoy!

Painting (optional)

I used Testors Red model paint to add some color to the "HOT" label at the front of part 3. It was tedious (steady hand required).

Tools used for design:

I simply measured the base of the cup-holder in the LEAF, and the height. Then I built everything in TinkerCad. http://tinkercad.com

title: Y Bed wire management (Prusa i3 and clones)

description.text:
Wire management for Prusa i3 and clones to prevent bed heater wires from getting overly stressed and breaking or shorting out. version for left and right of center depending you your printer and were/how the motor and such are mounting.

Mount to the lower carriage plate of the bed . There is NO mounting screw hole as there is just too many different beds out there. Print up and either drill out or just hold the screw over a candle and heat up and poke through the plastic.

Recommend printing with high shell/outer layer but inners can be low (wouldn't go under 20% though personally)

title: Bottom mounting plate for Velleman MK138 Thermostat board

description.text: This is a simple board to mount your MK138 circuit board to. It's 62mm x 52.5mm. The base is 3mm thick. The 4 posts start out as 6mm diameter for 5mm then go to 3mm for 3mm.

Print as you normally would but best results are done on a heated bed. The original was made on a SeeMeCNC H-1 printer with 1.75mm filament. Here's the Slic3r settings used: ; layer_height = .3
; perimeters = 3
; solid_layers = 3
; fill_density = .4
; nozzle_diameter = .508
; filament_diameter = 1.75
; extrusion_multiplier = 1
; perimeter_speed = 30
; infill_speed = 30
; travel_speed = 300
; extrusion_width_ratio = 0
; scale = 1
; single wall width = 0.71mm After you snap the circuit board on to the bottom plate, you can use a heat source to melt the tops of the 3mm studs sticking through the circuit board to keep it on.

title: Calibration/Optimization Tower for 5 conditions at a time

description.text:
I designed this 25mm tall tower so I could test 5 conditions at once using Simplify3D. For each 5mm section I can use a different condition.

Simplify3D instructions

  • import this STL file once
  • create 5 similar processes
  • In each process, go to the "avanced" tab and change the start and stop printing height (0 to 5 mm, 5 to 10 mm, 10 to 15 mm, etc)
  • Now in each process vary one parameter. For example vary retraction settings from disabled, to 0.2mm, 0.4mm, 0.6mm, 0.8mm, 1mm.
  • Print and pick the best!

This lamp is made in three parts, The post has threads on either end, which screw into the base and top. This was designed to put LEDs in through the holes in the top and pulled down through the hole at the treads. The post has clips at the top and bottom to hole LEDs that will shine down ito the post, as the post has gaps in which light may shine through. This lamp stands about 18 cm. tall and about 13 cm. at the base. It is scaled specifically to hold leds of 0.5 cm diameter or larger. This is my first serious creation. Thanks to the three designers that created some of the parts I used.

P.S.- For those who need a battery holder I have included one I made. All you will need is meatl tabs for it.

author: DiamondDiggers

description.text:
Make it climb

https://youtu.be/3sg1ElKSOP0

Greg Gzumwalt (gzumwalt) brings 3D printed parts to life. He demonstrates that in more than 100 designs on Thingiverse. Inspired by all this motion, this ”thing” is a modest contribution. It’s a version of the power source of that very old (first seen in 1903) children’s toy, the Lehmann climbing monkey. The engine is constructed in such a way that it can be inserted in toys. A bear, a helicopter or whatever. In this thing we construct an Angry Bird, or something that looks like one.
The two wheels of the engine snap-lock together . Make sure the holes for fixing the strings are at the outside. Shift them into the housing and push the square shaft from one side of the housing to the other side. However, before you do that, cut a small piece from both ends of the shaft to remove print imperfections and remove sharp edges with sandpaper. Move the end caps with “wing” over the square shaft ends. They should go into the openings of the housing since they act as bearings. As you can see, I am not a great wing designer (although I am an aerospace engineer). So, replace the wings with your own design.
The string that comes from the larger diameter goes through the bottom hole, while the string wound on the smaller diameter goes through the top hole.
Wind the string once around the small wheel and leave it long. Make as many windings as possible on the larger diameter and you only need some remaining length to fasten it to the pull ring. Both strings should leave the wheels at the same side when they go to the escape holes. The exact length of the strings is determined by experiment. Just pull the lower string and change the number of windings on the small diameter until you are happy with it.
Although supports are not really necessary for the engine housing, you might want to have some support for the shaft bearing to make it look nicer. But since it is at the inside of the housing, it is not really important. The wheel combination should rotate without friction. The Angry Bird is formed by two simple spheres. By printing the x- and y-axis at 100% but the z-axis at 200%, it fits nicely around the engine. This part is printed twice, with supports. Eyes and beak are improvised, I am sure you can do better.
More climbing "Things":
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1918477
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1930503
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1943901

description.text:
After messing around with bearings and magnets and spending lot of time to get those complicated stuff to fit together I was not happy with all that stuff. So I went back to a much simplier design, where no bearuings and no magnets are needed. Tension comes just from the plastic and so all you need is the 3 parts printed out, 2 pins (nails in my case), some wire, the female part of a 7mm bullet plug (I used this, because I have plenty of them in my spare parts box from unsoldering it from LiPos). If you want to be able to adjust the gap, you need 2 pcs. of M2 bolts. I used one from left overs I have tons from helicopter built.

In the pictures you see all you should know for putting it together. If you want it a little bit cleaner, you can use epoxy instead of hot glue. I prefer hot glue, but it's a bit of a mess with the strings you get. After all is put together, you do not see it though.

For connecting it to the keyer or your rig, you can use an audio cable with a 3,5mm plug, if you use a socket, like I do. You can see that on the pictures. You could also just solder the cable directly to the pins and the center piece. Then just put the cable through the whole in the case, before you solder it together ;-) and don't forget some kind of strain reliefe (cable tie and/or hotglue/epoxy, etc.)

For me that paddle works amazingly well. I do not have any longtime experience though. Printed it in PLA so do not use when it is hotter than 60C. ;-)

Other than you see on the fotos, I made a little change to the design of the case. Ther is a slot where the center pin fits tight into it. That is to avoid pushing the center agains the opposite contact, when working with a very tiny gap.

A "Dualstrusion" Replicator arrived Monday. I set it up on the kitchen table, leveled it - nice built in leveling algorithm - and printed a two color test cube - it was identical to the one that came with the printer - all in under three hours. Very nice! Models of the Archimedean solids are usually multicolored and make good test objects. While waiting for the Replicator I prepared a number of Archimedean solid models for two color printing. Here are four of them: 1) truncated tetrahedron, 2) cuboctohedron, 3) truncated cube, and 4) truncated octahedron Two stl files are included for each solid; trunc_tetrahedron_less_faces.stl and trunc_tetrahedron_faces.stl
cuboctahedron_less_faces.stl and cuboctahedron_faces.stl
trunc_cube_less_faces.stl and trunc_cube_faces.stl
trunc_octahedron_less_faces.stl and trunc_octahedron_faces.stl The files can be merged and printed in two colors. For those interested in the details a few words follow: The stl files were created with openSCAD. A zip file containing the open scad files is included - 2color_archi_scad_01.zip OpenSCAD's polyhedron command does most of the work. A hollow Archimedean solid from thing:17571 has two copies of the polyhedra, an outer copy and a smaller, but otherwise identical, inner copy. Suppose we wish to extract a single face, for example a pentagonal one. The coordinates of the vertices for the outer and inner pentagons are available from the hollow polyhedra scad file. These 10 coordinates define a polyhedron that corresponds to a face. It needs to be closed with 16 triangles, see the openSCAD manual for details Often a single openSCAD polyhedron command can be used to create a complete set of faces. However openSCAD does not work with shared vertices and where they occur shifts have to be made to avoid them. A program is needed to write the openSCAD commands as there is too much bookkeeping to keep track of without help. OpenSCAD's "thrown together" command can be used to catch errors.

There seem to be few parameters to set for dual color printing - at least I have yet to locate them.  The build surface needs to be carefully leveled as rafts evidently do not work.  The surface at right angles to the z axis is the one placed on the build surface.  The truncated cube printed perfectly but there were some smudges on one or two faces of the other solids although most of the wrong color can be scraped off.  It looks to be possible to minimize smudging by rotating the model around the z axis.
The fluorescent red and black models are striking - see image.

Soldering station like 936 and 937D come with interchangeable tips but nowhere to store them, so I created a holder that can store them neatly. Use a double-sided tape to mount it on the back of the soldering station. It blends in nicely when printed with a black filament.

print_settings.Notes:: Note that the Katadyn filter itself is made of ABS (at least the part that this object screws into). I don't think thread wear should be a problem, but you may want to avoid filaments that are abrasive or extremely hard.

description.text: This is a screw-in adapter for the Katadyn Combi that allows the water filter to stand upright when an outlet hose is attached to the bottom.

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro (2016)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

The threads need to be relatively smooth, so print in a high resolution or plan on smoothing it out after printing. Running the cooling fan might help.

The quality of the printed threads may be affected by your slicer software. For example, I noticed that Slic3r (at least how I had it set up) added little bumps between the threads. Other slicers didn't have this issue.

Note that the Katadyn filter itself is made of ABS (at least the part that this object screws into). I don't think thread wear should be a problem, but you may want to avoid filaments that are abrasive or extremely hard.

Designed in FreeCAD 0.16

I had to play around with the threading to get it to work without breaking the model's faces. Aside from avoiding overlapping faces, one of the biggest non-obvious steps was cutting the ends of the swept helix with primitive cubes before joining the threaded cylinder to the rest of the object.

Many attempts to taper the thread or to move the start of the threading down the cylinder breaks the model. After a lot of trial-and-error, I found the current model to be good enough - not as polished as I would've liked but functional nonetheless.

The STL was fixed in Netfabb before uploading to Thingiverse.

title: Central Machinery 4"x36" Belt Sander Wet/Dry Vac Sawdust Collector

description.text:
Introducing the attachment that will save you hours of cleanup. Upon testing the newly purchased Central Machinery 4"x36" belt and disk sander, I was shocked to find that it was almost unusable because of the amount of sawdust it produced. I was forced to put on some sealed safety goggles and a gas mask. To solve this problem, I designed a small attachment that allows you to connect a Wet/dry Vac up to your belt sander. It has an OD of 58mm to fit inside larger vac tubes, and an ID of 45.5mm to fit around smaller vac tubes. Now, all of the sawdust just gets sucked up the the vacuum. This makes your cleanup much easier. The bent part at the top of the attachment connects to a 5/8" ID flexible tube which then connects to the bottom guard on the disk sander, allowing you to collect ALL of the sawdust. For more information on the Central Machinery 4"x36" belt and disk sander and how to install this, check out our Unboxing, Assembly, Review, and Modification video.

If none of the measurements above fit your shop vac, easily modify it by changing the ID and OD variables at the top of our public Onshape design

Note: Photos are of an earlier version. Current design has a few minor changes.

Update: 1/8/2018 Because of high demand, I've designed a custom version for 1 1/4" fitting for smaller vacs. I've also increased the thickness of all of the walls to ensure that they don't break upon installation.

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Use your defaults

Infill:

10-20%

Notes:

Sadly, this design requires a good amount of supports. If your slicing program does not have good supports, I would strongly suggest that you look into Simplify 3D. It is a bit expensive but is totally worth it. Both supports and rafts on it just snap right off while giving you complete control over your print. When you do slice it, make sure that it is standing upward on the build platform to minimize supports and reduce print time (bent part should be at the top).

fach fuer kuehlschrank

Low budget surveillance system For Raspberry Pi Zero 1.3 only.
Printed in 0.1, ABS smoothed with acetone

M2.5 screw's head must be mount side of the Pi Zero, and nuts side of the Zero4U.

Soft used is motionEye with Raspbian Wheezy.
Dimensions of the camera took from raspberrypi-spy
Dimensions of the rpi took from raspiworld

I added ton of pictures including some macrographs, it need a bit of adjustments but looks already neat.
I've choose to don't make a hole for the Mini USB-b of the Zero4U due to the flex cable who obstruate him.

Hardware:

Raspberry Pi Zero - Version 1.3
Pi NoIR Camera Board rev 2.1 8MP
Raspberry Pi Zero camera adapter flex cable
Zero4U: 4-Port USB Hub for Raspberry Pi Zero (V1.3 only)
USB to Micro USB with ON/OFF Switch Charger Power Cable for Raspberry Pi
Wifi dongle RT5370

up to 3 others usb camera with the rest of free USB.

comments.text: Be aware that the Zero4U Rev 2 add-on for the Raspberry Pi Zero 1.3, had a slightly different placement of the white power plug. This case also does not expose the Mini-USB on the opposite side of the SD Micro card, which can be useful to power the unit with an older Mini USB cable. Anyhow, this looks like a great case which I will download and attempt to modify to fit the new rev 2 USB hat. Thanks for designing and making it public on Thingiverse! Much appreciated.

remixed_from.title: Tri-Track dual servo robot tank chassis

title: TOM Tri-Track dual servo robot tank chassis

description.text: This is a varient of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:14599 by Ktronics. The Tri-track frame is too large to print on a Thing-o-matic, so I've updated the design to split the frame into three parts which can be bolted together. I've also updated the drive wheels to include holes for mounting the servos, mounting holes in the frame for the servo mounts. As well as updated the servo mounts to be the correct size for the CSRC-311 servo. http://youtu.be/hBeYp6AdOhc The file "Stationary.ino" is a basic Arduino sketch which reads distance from two PING sensors, and does obstacle avoidance. It's named "Stationary" as that is my robot's name. He spent awhile without a brain, and thusly didn't move all that much, thus the name.

Print the following components: 2 - Tri-Track frame end segments
1 - Tri-Track frame middle segment
42 - Track Sections
2 - drive sprockets
4 - 608 idler sprockets
4 - 608 Bearings
2 - Servo Mounts The following hardware is required to assemble: 42 - M3 x 45mm socket cap bolt
42 - M3 nylon-insert hex locknut
8 - M3 x 15mm socket cap bolt
4 - M3 x 20mm socket cap bolt
6 - M3 x 25mm socket cap bolt
32 - M3 washer
4 - M4 x 16mm socket cap bolt
8 - M4 washer
2 - M8 x 160mm threaded rod
20 - M8 hex nut
16 - M8 washer Hardware can be found online through McMaster-Carr.

comments.text: Manually modeled in Sketchup.  There is software available for Eagle CAM which will render boards, but I never installed it, since you still need to create models of all your parts. For as often as I need that, it's easier to spend some time with some digital calipers and draw it out myself.
comments.author: claudiuc

comments.text: So far so good with my build.  Thanks for this.  I'm building it with my 7 year old daughter.  We have an uno, a due, and a mega.  It looks like the uno should work.  I can't see what shield you have stacked on there.  Can you point me in the right direction?
comments.author: quadmodder

comments.text: Yea, I'm using an Arduino UNO.  Though anything would work.  As for the shield, It's just a basic prototyping shield I used for mounting the servo headers, and the I2C switch I needed (which knowing what I know now, I would have just did better research on which sensors I was using to make sure you could change their I2C address so you could run more than one)  Then the top most is just some protoboard I made into a shield to mount the PING sensors, since I didn't like the idea of having a third servo to be able to sweep a single sensor back and forth.

remixed_from.author: iamjonlawrence
remixed_from.title: Timing Belt Y MXL, Printrbot Simple V2

title: Timing Belt X MXL, Printrbot Simple V2

description.text:
This will work for both V2 designs (with & w/o string tension) After successfully adding the timing belt to the Y axis, it was time to convert the X axis. Assembly method is similar to my Y axis conversion. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:180146 REV B:
  • Add alternate X Belt End Mirror for Simple V2 With string tension device (models ordered after 10-23-2013).
  • Add chamfer to belt ends to give a little more clearance for motor plate at both ends of travel.

Just a "head's up"  
In order to replace the X axis motor plate, ALL sides of the machine will have to be removed. This includes sliding the Z rods out of the base plate.  You don't have to remove them from the top plate, but they will need to come out of the bottom plate.  
The dis-assembly is more scary than difficult. Simply be mentally prepared for a complete dis-assembly of all sides and it won't be too bad.  
Your efforts WILL be rewarded, and you will not want to return to the string drive.  
Enjoy!

title: portable mast support plus balun holder

description.text:
I made a support for my portable fishing pole mast to keep the first element standing on it's own, without having an opportunity to tie it to something or to carry a tripod with you.
Just put the big ring on top of the thickest element of the pole and tie 3 lines to it and fix the lines on the ground with some pegs for example. After that you can bring up the pole and handle it without having someone to help you out with a third anf fourth hand.

The smaller ring is a rotary support. While the inner ring sticks by friction to the pole, the outer ring with the attache lines can ratate freely. That helps, wenn bringing up the pole and turn it to avoid the guy lines are turned around the pole.

The rotary ring prints as one part and then spins very smoothly.

The balun mounting thing is just a little helper to fix a small balun or something else on the top of the pole. I have to make a rotary version though, to not get the antenna wire wound around the pole when rotating the pole while bringing it up. Then it woul perfectly fit to the rotary support.

I hope my explanation is not too confusing ;-)

Printer:

Flashforge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

No

0.2mm

20% is enough. If you want it extrastrong make 100%.

comments.text:
use tent poles like this for portable antennas the part that slides in the other pole is about 40mm..I will try to resize in my slicer program
Thank you
comments.author: kodaknix

comments.text:
If you just somthing like the yellow part, resizing is simple, because no revolving parts involved. This is ment to sit on the first element of a pushup pole to hold it in place, while mounting the antenna wire and pushing up the pole. You can easy resize it to a diameter that fits snug on the upper end of your first element of the pole.
The revolving support is ment to be somewhere in the middle of the pole. I had issues with a fixed mount, because, when bringing up the pole, it need to be turned to have the elements friction fixed to each other. While turning I ended up winding the antenna wires and the guy wires around the pole. So I designed a guywire mount the revovolves with the pole in the inside, but stays in place on the outside.
comments.author: kodaknix

comments.text: what size poles?Will it fit Army tent ?
comments.author: kodaknix

comments.text:
I don't know what Army tent you mean. I made this for a pole to put up an antenna and I can scale it to any size I like.
You can even scale it in the slicer softare, but the spinning parts could get stuck, if you scale it down too much, as the gaps between the inner and the outer part wíll narrow down.
